anchor.surface_text: Under s. 67, if a document is alleged to be signed by any person, the signature of the said person must be proved to be in his handwriting,

concepts.interpretation: Requires proof of signature in handwriting for documents alleged to be signed

concepts.interpretation: Requires at least one attesting witness to prove execution of attested documents

anchor.surface_text: Section 63 requires that the testator shall sign or affix his mark to the will or it shall be signed by some other person in his presence and by his direction and that the signature or mark shall be so made that it shall appear that it was intended thereby to give effect to the writing as a will. This section also requires that the will shall be attested by two or more witnesses as prescribed.

concepts.interpretation: Requirements for execution and attestation of will: signature with intent, attestation by two witnesses

Will proved like any document but with special requirements of attestation; propounder must prove signature, sound mind, understanding of contents, free will; suspicious circumstances require removal of suspicion

issues.text: What is the true legal position in the matter of proof of wills?
the question as to whether the will set up by the propounder is proved to be the last will of the testator
Has the testator signed the will?
Did he understand the nature and effect of the dispositions in the will?
Did he put his signature to the will knowing what it contained?
whether the execution of the will may be surrounded by suspicious circumstances
whether all legitimate suspicions should be completely removed
Whether the appellant had established that Lakshmamma was the owner of the properties and entitled to dispose of them by will

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises from a suit brought by the appellant in the court of the Subordinate Judge, Mysore, as the sole executor of the will alleged to have been executed by one Lakshmamma on August 22, 1945, Ex. A . In this suit the appellant claimed a declaration that the said Lakshmamma was the owner of the properties mentioned in the schedule attached to the plaint and as such was entitled to dispose of them by a will

arguments.claim: Proof of signature on will presumes knowledge of contents
Since signature proved, presume valid execution and knowledge
arguments.court_reasoning: Applies only to wills free from suspicion; rebutted here

arguments.claim: Propounder must prove signature, sound mind, knowledge of contents, free will; suspicious circumstances increase onus
Suspicious circumstances surround execution: shaky signature, feeble mind, unnatural dispositions, propounder benefits and active
Will preamble argumentative recitals artificial, not from testatrix instructions
Dispositions unnatural: excludes grandchildren substantially, favors appellant's sons improbably

anchor.surface_text: The next circumstance which calls for an explanation is the exclusion of the grand-children of the testtatrix from any substantial legacies under the will.

arguments.claim: Propounder took prominent part in execution and sons benefit substantially, suspicious
Evidence of witnesses unsatisfactory: discrepancies, poor recall, inconsistencies
High Court not justified in deciding title issues after rejecting will proof

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial court on the question of the due and valid execution of the will Ex. A.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts then we are inclined to hold that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial court on the question of the due and valid execution of the will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious circumstances including artificial argumentative preamble, unnatural dispositions excluding grandchildren while benefiting propounder's sons, prominent role of propounder, and unsatisfactory evidence from witnesses not removed despite heavy onus.

holdings.text: A propounder of a will must prove by satisfactory evidence that the testator signed the will, was in sound and disposing state of mind, understood the nature and effect of the dispositions, and executed it voluntarily; suspicious circumstances require the propounder to remove all legitimate suspicions by cogent evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from ss. 67, 68 Evidence Act, ss. 59, 63 Succession Act, and precedents like Barry v. Butlin, Fulton v. Andrew, Tyrrell v. Painton; standard is satisfaction of prudent mind/judicial conscience, heightened onus under suspicion.

holdings.text: The execution of the will was surrounded by suspicious circumstances such as artificial preamble, unnatural dispositions, and propounder's prominent role and benefit to his sons.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Preamble contains argumentative recitals anticipating objections; excludes grandchildren substantially; favors appellant's sons improbably given family relations; appellant drafted, dictated, and his sons benefit substantially.

holdings.text: The appellant failed to satisfactorily discharge the heavy onus of removing the suspicious circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of witnesses shows discrepancies, poor recollection, inconsistencies; no independent corroboration of instructions or full understanding; scribe's account differs; no proof draft read to testatrix.

holdings.text: Proof of the testatrix's signature on the will does not raise an irrebuttable presumption of knowledge of contents where suspicious circumstances exist.

anchor.surface_text: the learned trial judge appears to have misdirected himself in law inasmuch as he thought that the proof of the signature of the testatrix on the will raised a presumption that the will had been executed by her. In support of this view the learned judge has referred to the decision of the Calcutta High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption from signature under s.67 Evidence Act is rebuttable by suspicious circumstances; trial judge erred by applying it absolutely without assessing suspicions.

holdings.text: The allegation that Lakshmamma signed the will at five places is proved.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Conceded based on evidence; no dispute on handwriting proof.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in recording findings on title issues (source of purchase money for items 3-5 and Lakshmamma's interest in gift properties) after holding the will not proved, as those issues did not survive.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Once will proof fails, title issues unnecessary; High Court observations obiter, inadequately reasoned, and open to challenge; expressly not decided here.

anchor.surface_text: as observed by Lord Du Parcq in Harmes v. Hinkson 1 where a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, number an obdurate persistence in disbelief. They do number demand from the judge, even in circumstances of grave suspicion, a resolute and impenetrable incredulity. He is never required to close his mind to the truth .

precedents.cited_proposition: where a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, not obdurate persistence in disbelief

anchor.surface_text: According to the decisions in Fulton v. Andrew 1 those who take a benefit under a will, and have been instrumental in preparing or obtaining it, have thrown upon them the onus of showing the righteousness of the transaction .

precedents.cited_proposition: those who take a benefit under a will and instrumental in preparing it have onus to show righteousness

anchor.surface_text: Lord Cairns, has cited with approval the well-known observations of Baron Parke in the case of Barry v. Butlin 1 . The two rules of law set out by Baron Parke are first, that the onus probandi lies in every case upon the party propounding a will

precedents.cited_proposition: two rules: onus on propounder to satisfy conscience; suspicion if propounder writes and benefits

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was emphasized by the Privy Council inVellasawmy Servai v. Sivaraman Servai 1 , where it was held that, where a will is propounded by the chief beneficiary under it, who has taken a leading part in giving instructions for its preparation and in procuring its execution, probate should number be granted unless the evidence removes suspicion

precedents.cited_proposition: chief beneficiary propounder taking leading part must remove suspicion

precedents.citation: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 2

anchor.surface_text: In Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 2 , the Privy Council made it clear that the principle which requires the propounder to remove suspicions from the mind of the Court is number companyfined only to cases where the propounder takes part in the execution of the will and receives benefit under it.

precedents.case_name: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: principle applies to other suspicious circumstances besides propounder benefiting

anchor.surface_text: This view is supported by the observations made by Lindley and Davey, L. JJ., in Tyrrell v. Painton 3 . The rule in Barry v. Butlin 4 , Fulton v. Andrew 5 and Brown v. Fisher 6 , said Lindley, J., is number in my mind companyfined to the single case

precedents.cited_proposition: rule extends to all cases with circumstances exciting suspicion

precedents.citation: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas 1

anchor.surface_text: In Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas 1 it appeared that though the will was fairly simple and number very long the making of it was from first to last the doing of Khetter, the manager and trusted adviser of the alleged testator.

precedents.case_name: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: leading role by adviser in simple will raises suspicion

precedents.citation: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi 1

anchor.surface_text: The case of Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi 1 , on the other hand, was the case of a will the execution of which was held to be number surrounded by any suspicious circumstances.

precedents.case_name: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: no suspicion if propounder is natural beneficiary like adopted son

anchor.surface_text: In Bai Gungabai v. Bhugwandas Valji. 3 , the Privy Council had to deal with a will which was admitted to probate by the first companyrt, but on appeal the order was varied by excluding therefrom certain passages

precedents.cited_proposition: onus on benefiting solicitor, but discharged on evidence

anchor.surface_text: In Perera v. Perera 2 it was held that when the testator is of sound mind when he gives instructions for a will but at the time of signature accepts the instrument drawn in pursuance thereof without being able

precedents.cited_proposition: sound mind at instructions suffices if accepts will later believing it carries them out

anchor.surface_text: following the observations of Sir James Hannen in Parker v. Felgate 1 that if a person has given instructions to a solicitor to make a will and the solicitor prepares it in accordance with those instructions, all that is necessary to make it a good will if executed by the testator is that he should be able to think thus far

precedents.cited_proposition: instructions followed faithfully, testator accepts believing so

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which reference must be made is the decision of the Privy Council in Harmes v. Hinkson 1 It appears that, in this case, the testator George Harmes died in the city of Regina on April 4, 1941.

precedents.cited_proposition: deference to trial judge's findings on credibility

precedents.citation: Powell v. Streatham ManoR Nursing Home 1

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships then referred with approval to the principles which had been frequently enunciated as to the respect which the appellate companyrt ought to pay to the opinion which a Judge who has watched and listened to the witness has formed as to their credibility  Powell v. Streatham ManoR Nursing Home 1 .

precedents.case_name: Powell v. Streatham Manor Nursing Home
precedents.cited_proposition: appellate court respect for trial judge's credibility assessment

precedents.citation: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of this view the learned judge has referred to the decision of the Calcutta High Court in Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji 1 . In this case numberdoubt the Calcutta High Court has held that on the proof of the signature of the deceased or his acknowledgment that he has signed the will he will be presumed to have known the provisions of the instrument

precedents.case_name: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji
precedents.cited_proposition: presumption from proof of signature that testator knew contents
precedents.cited_holding: presumption liable to be rebutted by suspicious circumstances
